raw_text: The Devil Came Down To Georgia, but Johnny was answering writing prompts, and the Devil bet a keyboard of gold against his soul that he could get more upvotes.
requirements: Feel free to use creativity to expand on the prompt and create an interesting and captivating narrative.
Ensure the story is no shorter than 8000 words.
label:
After swiftly defeating the Devil with his story about a sad rhinoceros, Johnny loaded the gold keyboard into his Honda and drove back to Savannah.

The next morning, he woke up to a text.

"Hey... it's the Devil. Can we talk?"

He pocketed his phone without responding and went in for his shift at Starbucks--where Terry, his manager, was in one of his moods. Great. As usual, Johnny found solace in the milk frother, the display pastries, all the beautiful, humdrum minutiae of another Monday.

During his lunch break, his phone buzzed with another text.

"That keyboard was my dad's," it said.

WTF? The Devil has a dad?

Johnny pocketed the phone without responding and went back inside. The minute he got back into the air conditioning, a third text came in.

"Ur the real bad guy here," it said. "Dick. Please call me."

That was it. As he returned to the counter, he felt his temper rising, and he began to tap out a response--but almost immediately, Terry caught him. "Johnny!" he snapped. "Who could you possibly be texting in the middle of your shift?"

You know what? No more tip-toeing around Terry. If he wanted answers, he'd get answers, gosh darn it. "The Devil,' Johnny said--but before he could savor the surprise on his manager's face, his phone buzzed.

The Devil was calling him now.

In the parking lot, Johnny answered. "Dude. You're not getting the keyboard back. Okay? I won it fair and square. Get over it." He laughed, angry, incredulous. "I mean, you wrote your story in freaking Sumerian cuneiform. What did you think would happen?"

"I know. I know." The voice on the other end sounded hurt. "It's just--I don't know, man."

"You don't know what?"

Silence.

Johnny softened his tone. "You don't know what?" he asked again, gently.

"Do you think we can still be friends?"

Welp, no good way to answer that. They'd only met yesterday! Johnny stared across the parking lot, his stomach turning. Then again, if he could stand up to Terry, he could stand up to the Prince of Darkness. "No," he said at last. "I'm sorry."

The Devil thought a moment. "Can I still see the keyboard on weekends, at least?"

raw_text: Like a snake that shed its skin, you shed your human body. Every two weeks, you take the form of another person entirely. From age, to gender and race, you are completely unsure who you will become every other week.
requirements: Feel free to use creativity to expand on the prompt and create an interesting and captivating narrative.
Ensure the story is no shorter than 8000 words.
label:
Having a condition that completely alters your gender and race after every two weeks is troubling. It's especially troubling if you're head over heels in love.

This condition started when I turned of age. Barring the obvious legal and administrative issues I face due to the lack of a national identity as a citizen, my identity in and of itself is coming into question. If I didn't have old photos of myself prior to the development of the condition, I would have lost all sense of continuity long ago.

I constantly feel like I'm losing myself. Everything I thought I knew about who I am would run away with its tail tucked in between its legs after every two weeks. Every attempt at forming connections gets caught up in a cycle that ultimately ends with me watching them unravel. Living is disorienting and ultimately exhausting.

There is no constant, but her.

"Of course, what is it?" I answered, my full attention now belonging to the woman. This wasn't our first glance shared, but seemed to be our first full conversation. We shared greetings on a near day to day basis, with her jogging, and me, feeding the ducks bread crumbs.

The autumn breeze carried a gentle whisper, causing the amber trees to rustle and leaves drift hazily to the ground.

The woman cleared her throat, almost as if it served as a preface to a big revelation. "Weren't you an Asian woman just the other day? A white man the other week? An Asian man the other week behind that other week? Well, you get the idea..."

I was stunned. Utterly and woefully stunned. I couldn't answer, and instead, I shrugged.

"Is that so? I go to the park everyday, and no one else feeds the ducks breadcrumbs but you!" She said, brazenly said, sounding confident at the bizarrely correct conclusion she came up with, pointing cheekily at me.

We only ever shared greetings, but there was always something so special about her body language.

I shrugged again. "I just moved here. I'm afraid you have the wrong person," I said, looking away from her, turning my attention to the ducks as memories of my past identities filled the space behind my eyes. "The Asian woman you were referring to could be Veronica however, she lives a few blocks away from here. I met her the other day."

The woman didn't seem convinced, as her once big smile strained and turned into an ever so slightly smaller one. "Well, if you say so. I can't argue with that," she said, putting her index finger on her chin. "That being the case though, I am not convinced! Hehe." She finished, sneaking that jab in.

I didn't know what to say in retort. Seconds would threaten to drag into a minute if I didn't respond. To my surprise, however, she opened her mouth first.

"Can I at least ask for your name?"

I didn't know the answer to that. Well I did, but I couldn't help but interpret multiple implications at the innocent question due to my condition.

"Vivi," I answered.

"Vivi! Alright! You didn't ask, but my name's Hanna. I'll be continuing my jog now, see ya around!" She said, as she readied herself up for a jogging stance, proceeding to jog, shortly after.

I watched for a moment, stared at her jogging away and held back the words in my throat. The tightness in my chest twisted inward, clenching harder, tighter, and with gradually more force.

I hope she already has someone. If not, fall in love with another. I know for sure I would never fall out of it.

I thought, as I decided that this was the last slice of bread I'm feeding to these ducks.

raw_text: Malicious traffic light that knows exactly what it's doing.
requirements: Feel free to use creativity to expand on the prompt and create an interesting and captivating narrative.
Ensure the story is no shorter than 8000 words.
label:
Mark slammed his fists against the steering wheel and flung out his arms.

"Again! COME ON!"

The traffic light had been green so briefly. He'd hit the gas and then the brake because as soon as it was green, it was red again. It skipped yellow! Why was the danged thing skipping yellow! A chorus of honks behind him.

"Just be patient Mark," Phil said sipping some coffee from his tervis. "Don't give the jerk the satisfaction."

"WHAT are you talking about?"

"Quit giving the light the satisfaction of your anger, just ignore it. Be casual."

Phil made a surfing motion then set his cup in the cup holder. He had his leg crossed over his knee in the passenger seat and was reading some sort of puppeteer magazine. Mark's grip was so tight around the steering wheel he felt he could snap the thing off the van and chuck it out into traffic.

The light flashed green. Mark put his foot on the gas. Red. He shook with anger as he slammed his foot down on the brake. Another chorus of honks. He rolled down the window, ready to yell at everyone, but Phil grabbed his shoulder.

"Look man, this light up here is like one of your Internet trolls. It does it on purpose. You've got to relax and quit feeding it."

"That doesn't. Make. Any. Sense." Mark said through grit teeth as he jammed this finger down on the window button rolling it back up.

Phil shrugged. "We're gonna be late unless it does make sense. The show is in thirty minutes, Mark, and we gotta set up. We can't sit here forever."

Mark let out a deep sigh. What was up with this town? A little green man worked at City Hall and now a sentient traffic light that loved ruining people's day. Mark checked his phone. They really were going to be late.

A chorus of honks. Mark looked up just in time to see the light turn yellow, then red. Oh, so now it can flash yellow. He felt so much rage he was calm. He shook for a minute then became really still. He stared forward.

Mark was never leaving this spot. This was Hell. This was Purgatory. He could think of a few things he'd done to be punished, but not punished like this. No one deserved this. Dear God, can't the light just change. What was the traffic lights deal? Drunk with power? Girlfriend broke up with him? Mark laughed to himself. No, this was crazy. Mark tapped the steering wheel with his fingers. Maybe he had bird poop all down his back and was making it everyone else's problem.

"Now, you're getting it," Phil smiled. "Green light."

Mark absentmindedly hit the gas and passed under the green light. Phil flipped a page in his magazine.

"See, Mark. You did it." Phil said.

Mark blinked. "I guess I did."

"It wasn't so bad. He never holds like that for long. You just gotta stay calm, stay smooth."

They rode up the street and down another. He turned into the school parking lot. Some staff were waiting for them. They rushed out to help them get their stuff and bring it to the auditorium.

Phil sipped his coffee one last time before tossing his magazine on to the dash and hopping out. Mark wasn't driving ever again. Ever, ever, again. Not down that street.

raw_text: You are "The Orphan", the only supervillain that is not outright hated. You show no mercy on heroes that have collateral, especially those that leave children without parents.
requirements: Feel free to use creativity to expand on the prompt and create an interesting and captivating narrative.
Ensure the story is no shorter than 8000 words.
label:
The news rippled through the city like a gunshot. The Flying Fox had walked into the middle of Times Square, pulled out a pistol and shot a woman in the face.

The Flying Fox. The paragon of justice. The protector of the innocence. A martial artist of the highest calibre, he was known to leave the goons he apprehended in the recovery position.

We had met for the first time 12 months prior, when I'd caught him talking down his murderous protege BloodCap. The red and black ninja had "accidentally" killed the parents of a family of four during a protracted battle with the (also killed) Mouseket Man. The Flying Fox was lecturing him on the perils of capital justice when I appeared behind BloodCap and tore his throat out.

Instead of attacking me, The Flying Fox had simply nodded and flown off into the night. In that moment, I thought he understood me. That I understood him. He couldn't kill, but surely he couldn't abide a man like BloodCap to live. That is why I exist. BloodCap would never see justice for what he did to that family. For those children he left...

And now, a year later, The Flying Fox has appeared in the middle of the city, in broad daylight, and murdered a woman as she stood next to a pram. It is as much a call to action as the weird spotlight the pigs shine on the clouds at night to get TFF's attention. It has to be a trap, and yet, what trap could they lay to catch me? To stop me?

The Ultronian is already there when I arrive. 'The only being in the universe that could stop me', many news stories have been written about how I exist at His leisure. That I operate with His tacit approval, because otherwise He would have stopped me years ago. The Ultronian is a god on this planet, after all. But he and I both know the truth. There is nothing the extra-terrestrial can do to me now. Maybe decades ago, but I am far beyond his reach now.

The Ultronian is yelling at The Fox, begging him to explain himself. The Flying Fox stands there silent, his trademark grimace unflinching as a being with the power of 6 trillion A-bombs screams in his face. When The Fox sees me, the grimace turns to a smile.

The Ultronian is in front of me in an instant.

"You can't do this," the alien said, but my eyes are already locked with The Fox's. I walk forward, through The Ultronian, passing as if he doesn't exist. In this moment, he might as well not. I don't have to hear The Flying Fox out, but I am curious about the nature of the trap. There has to be one. The Ultronian's hand claps on my shoulder, and I feel his immense power as he tries to control my movement. That alone makes me seethe. I try to breathe through the anger, and my feet slip a little below me. I look down and the ground is slick with blood, the gore not yet still enough to have congealed into a tacky goop.

I flinch at the sight, my curly red hair flicking the Ultronian in the face, flinging him away into the sky as if he'd never existed. That won't have killed him, but he is gone for now. I return my gaze to The Flying Fox, whose smile has grown wider. Is he being mind-controlled? The grin is the trademark of his nemesis.

"It's all me in here," he growls, anticipating my line of thinking. That is one of his gifts. He is always moves ahead.

"So what's the game here Fox," I ask, stepping out of the pooling blood and closer to him. "If this is a trap, just spring it already."

"The Orphan," he replies in his raspy monotone. "Real name Annie Gray. Lost her parents at seven during a clash between the Sandwich Man and the Sensational Six. Known to be responsible for 86 hero deaths. Impervious to harm, powered by spite, The Orphan kills any superbeing responsible for collateral damage resulting in the loss of life of an innocent. Trademark: A simple throat rip."

"Yeah, I've read my wikipedia entry," I reply flatly. I take another step forward. One more and I'll be in 'throat rip' range.

"You're the ultimate protector of those who cannot protect themselves," The Flying Fox continues, as if I hadn't spoken. "Dealing out "justice" as you see fit to any and all metahumans who deserve it. Both good and bad."

"If your plan is to lull me to sleep with monotonous exposition, I should warn you that I don't need to sleep any more." I take another step forward, and I lift my arm up to demonstrate my relative range.

"If you only kill metahumans," The Flying Fox says, a tinge of nervousness rippling through the gravel. "I should warn you that I am not one."

My hand drops back down again. Surprise washes over The Fox's face for a moment. That can't be the plan though. "I... you can't be serious. I don't exclusively kill metas. You can't have thought I'd let you live just because you don't have powers."

The Flying Fox's grin skews to one side. "No, I didn't. But I wanted to see your reaction."

My eye twitches and I feel my power grow. "Alright, well, it's weird for you to do this when you could have just asked, but I appreciate the commitment to the bit." I lift my arm towards him, and he... steps back.

"Wait," The Fox says quickly. "You don't care how I keep up with the metas despite having no powers?"

"You're rich," I say, shaking my head at the rhetoric. "Your teeth are a dead giveaway. Every time you open your mouth, everyone knows you're rich beyond measure. If you try to bribe me, I am going to make yet another exception, and before I kill you I will hurt you."

"I am. I am rich. And do you know where my money goes?"

"Dental work and fetish wear."

"Orphanages."

I let my arm fall again, and I exhale deeply. "Ok, go on." I say. Damn my insatiable curiosity.

"I, like you, grew up without parents," The Fox says. "Grew up an orphan. Except I grew up wanting for nothing. You... I know you had the hard-knock life. I have used my incredible wealth to fund orphanages around the world. The children who wind up at them want for nothing. There have been cases where parents have deliberately gotten themselves killed in meta conflicts so that their children might wind up at one of my boarding schools."

I put the details together in a heartbeat. "You're... you're Oliver Warbucks?" My jaw slackens.

"I am," says a voice, no longer the rasping growl of The Flying Fox but the rich, heartwarming timbre of the man they call "The World's Daddy". I stumble back a step in shock. "You and I are a lot alike," he continues. "We both see the impact metahumans have on this world. We both know that something must be done to safeguard against them."

"Why..." I stutter. "Why would you do this?"

"To show you that there must be a different way," he replies, his voice warm and soft and soothing. Listening to him is like being wrapped in a bear hug and squeezed full of love. I take another step back. My heel sticks to the asphalt for a second and I glance down. The blood from the woman has started to dry, and I remember why I'm here.

"There isn't." I snarl in reply, and I step towards him again.

His head tilts. "But there's more yet you don't know," he says. There is no The Flying Fox any more, just Oliver Warbucks, the philanthropist who owns orphanages around the world. The man who saves young children and sees that they lead the lives of their dreams.

"Spit it out Warbucks," I say as I reach ripping distance again.

"If you kill me, every single one of my orphanages will be dissolved. Dismantled. Destroyed. I had my will amended, witnessed and notarised. If you kill me, those children will be out on the street by nightfall tonight."

The power in me surges, a roaring torrent of rage. "That's it? That's your plan? Newsflash, "Daddy", but amending your will to do something bananas and then walking outside and committing murder-suicide doesn't paint the picture of a sound mind."

"It's airtight, Annie," he says softly. "The Will was amended 11 months ago. I've spent the last year passing mental health checks. This isn't something I did on a whim."

"Alright," I spit back. "So some kids get tricked instead of treated. They won't be the first, and they won't be the last. Why would that stop me from killing you?"

"I suppose it mightn't," he said in his fatherly, compassionate voice, "but it might make you admit to yourself that you kill for reasons beyond some higher pursuit of justice."

I sigh. "You couldn't find a tram for this half-baked trolley problem gambit?" I sneer. "Do you know how many collateral deaths there were before I existed? What about after? I'm not pulling a lever, you dumbass, I am the fucking trolley. Every time one of you heroes goes out and decides to stroke your own ego by beating up the mentally ill, I am the reason you're all careful not to hurt anyone else. I'm also the reason The Puffin King is content to bloodlessly escape the Hudson Street Asylum and why The Fool's guns all shoot flags that say bang. Did you really think I hadn't considered the philosophical circumstances of my existence? I told you I don't sleep."

I step to the caped man and raise my hand to his throat, but in the blink of an eye another throat is in my grasp. The Ultronian is back. His face is bruised, and he looks deeply out of breath.

"Wait, Orphan," he says. My hand relaxes from his neck. "You can't kill The Flying Fox."

"I can," I retort drily. "I'll show you."


"No, you can't," the Ultronian says, his hands up, shaking. He is scared. Truly scared. "You mustn't. Tomorrow the Nibiru arrives. A being greater than you or I or anything we can fathom. It exists beyond the limits of reason. Of our reason, anyway. But The Flying Fox can defeat it. I don't know how, I don't know why, but the Deus 10 machine was certain. The Flying Fox is the only thing that can stop the Nibiru. If he dies, humanity is doomed."

"Tomorrow," I laugh. It is a mean, bitter chuckle. Everything with these people is for some moment that hasn't happened yet. For some time that might not ever be. "Tomorrow? That will always be a day away. We live in the present, and we suffer our consequences in the here and now."

Behind the three of us, the baby in the pram begins crying. It has been so quiet this whole time, but now it is awake and missing its mother. Would always miss its mother. It is time to finish this. The Ultronian's face skews in panic, and he throws a wild strike my way. It lands. The Ultronian can't stop me, but he is still a being of staggering power. I feel my ribs crack as the alien's fist drives into the side of my breast. The anger I feel at the audacity of the attack repairs me even as it destroys me, but the pain is still real. I black out for a brief second, and when I come too I am three miles in the air and climbing. The Ultronian is dragging me with him to space. I reach up and push the super being into the Andromeda Galaxy, phasing through his hand as I do. I can't fly, so I have to fall back to the ground.

When I land 30 seconds later, The Flying Fox is cradling the baby in his arms. "This baby will have a wonderful life, Annie," says Warbucks. "But only if you let me live."

I shake my head at him and I cross the space between us in a heartbeat. My hand grabs his throat.

"Wait Annie," he says, his warm voice strangled. "You don't want to orphan this child do you?"

I hold him still, and I say nothing. "She's mine, Annie. This baby had a mother, yes. And I loved her dearly. And 12 months ago, using my fortune, the greatest science known to man and a bit of luck, we conceived this beautiful little miracle. My own little girl."

My fury flares like a supernova. It takes everything in me to stop from tearing The Flying Fox apart atom by atom. "You shot your own wife?!"

"I had to," says Warbucks. He is weeping uncontrollably. "Don't you understand? I had to. And now, if you kill me, you'll be orphaning this little girl. My little Annie."

"You..." I am lost for words for a moment. "You named her Annie?"

"After you, of course. Of course I did. She's a tribute to you Annie. To one of the greatest heroes the world has ever known. What other name could she have?"

A bitter taste fills my mouth. "Sentimentality? So that's your final play? Maybe The Orphan is a sentimental idiot?"

"No," he says, stiffly shaking his head around my hand. "Everything I said is sincere. I want you to understand that if you kill me, you will be orphaning this little girl. You kill metas that make orphans right? So if what I did was suicidal, then what you're about to do is suicidal too."

I stare at him. It feels like hours pass. Beneath my hand, The Flying Fox gently rocks baby Annie back to sleep. He seems sincere. Genuine. Like a good man backed into a corner somehow. Forced to do the unthinkable. I think I understand how he feels.

"So be it," I say, and I rip his throat out like pulling a tissue from a box. I grab little orphan Annie as her father's corpse falls to the floor, and I place her back in her pram.

And then I place my hand around my windpipe and pull.

raw_text: You're a villain, but you typically hold back. You're into villainy for a quick robbery, or just some laughs. But not any more. Today is the day to show them that making you mad is a BAD idea.
requirements: Feel free to use creativity to expand on the prompt and create an interesting and captivating narrative.
Ensure the story is no shorter than 8000 words.
label:
I'm not a bad guy, not really. Sure they gave me the label of "villian", but I saw that as saying I belonged in a Disney movie, taking my anger out on pathetic little Princesses.

Royalty wasn't really my game though. Nah, I never bothered myself with targeting Monarchs. I prefered to keep things much more low key.

My town may have known my name, but I had the ability to remain anonymous everywhere else.

My "villiany" existed out of boredom. I targeted banks and city buildings. Stole enough to keep things interesting then left humorous clues to my identity.

It was harmless, no real victims just corporations and the occasional millionaire CEO.

The local social media groups seemed to get a kick out of my actions. Many were struggling with the control these corporations had over their lives. Someone taking subtle revenge seemed to spur them on, give them hope.

I never hurt anyone. I never took from those who needed it. While the corporations saw me as a villian, many citizens saw me as somewhat of a Robin Hood.

No one was ever meant to get hurt.

Then, they made me mad...

You should never give someone the title "villan" and make them mad!

Some wise guy CEO decided he was sick and tired of my antics and he was going to put a stop to it. Get this... He doned a lyrica suit... Mask, Cape, underwear on the outside the whole works. Dude had been watching way too many super hero movies.

Dressed in this ridiculous get up he decides that instead of going toe to toe with me he'd go behind my back and kidnap my children.

Like I said... Don't give someone the title "villian" and make them mad.

You definitely don't call someone a "villian" and kidnap their children. Their life blood.

I didn't need any fancy costume; jeans, a polo shirt and my New Balance sneakers had always worked for me.

One thing about fancy costumes. They don't hide finger prints. I was smart enough to wear gloves during my crimes. While it took months for the public to uncover my identity, it took me just a few hours to uncover the identity of the foolishly dressed avenger.

It was a foolish young CEO, a self-proclaimed Alpha type. He'd talked a lot of smoke about his top notch security sytsem and team. I mean, they weren't that top notch. I'd emptied his Headquarters, safety deposit box and home within hours. I walked straight past the top notch security team and not a single camera or alarm system caught me.

I'd laughed when he'd sworn revenge. I guess that was my downfall, I got arrogant. Thought I was invincible. And I was.

My family however, weren't. I should have prepared them, taught them to defend themselves. At least thought realistically about the risks to my family.

Instead my arrogance put my family in harm's way.

So my family had been kidnapped and I had no idea what this crazed fool in lyrca was going to do to them. I wasn't waiting around to find out.

As a rule I didn't cause harm, I only targeted billionaire corporations and their overpaid CEOs.

But this lycra wearing fool threw the rule book out the window. I would do whatever needed to ensure my family's safety.

My crimes had been successful due to me possessing a special set of skills. Skills that gave me the ability to manuever through facilities completely undetected. It had only been through an arrogant mistake had my identity ever been revealed in the first place. Arrogance was a dangerous flaw to possess and the downfall of many great men.

My New Balance sneakers gave me the power I needed to kick down the Lyrca'd Fool's front door.

"Took you long enough!" The fool laughed as the dust cleared from the fallen door.

"It took you 6 years to find me. I found you in less than 6 hours. If you really want to talk about who took long enough... Where are they?"

I searched the room before he even had a chance to respond. I knew they wouldn't be in the front room, but I'd hoped to find some sort of false door or something. There had been nothing. I'd search the rest of the house when he took his next breath,

"Revenge is best delivered when its least expected,"

"I disagree. My best revenge is going to be exactly when you expect it. Where are my family?" There was a split second glance towards the stairs and I was gone.

A secret door in the furthest room. The fool would realise I was gone soon. My speed allowed me quite the advantage.

The secret door was built with reinforced steel. As if that could keep me out. Slow me down, yes, but keep me out? Never!

I heard the fool's footsteps at the top of the stairs as I threw my body against the door one last time. The hinges creaked then gave way opening to a dark unfinished room.

"DADDY!" My five year old screamed, "I'm scared," he muttered as he buried into my chest, "Hi Scared, I'm Dad!" I smirked, my wife smacked my arm as my son groaned at the joke.

"We don't have much time! Put these on. One each!" I pulled off my New Balance sneakers and handed them to my family.

"They'll keep you safe,"

"How?"

"They're magic!" I whispered to my son.

"Now, put them on and go. Take the car, it's already packed. Drive until you run out of fuel, refill and then keep driving," I explained to my wife as I tighly tied the oversized shoe on my son's foot.

"What about you?" My wife asked,

"I have to handle things here first, then I'll come find you. Now go!!" I shoved my family out of the secret room and towards the stairs, "RUN! Don't stop!"

I watched my wife and young son disappear out of the room as the fool got closer. They would pass him without him seeing and be gone from the property before he finally reached the secret room.

I pulled a new pair of New Balance out of my backpack and crouched to tie them. I heard laughter at the door and turned to see the fool had finally made it.

"You're exactly where I want you!" He laughed, grabbing the heavy door and beginning to push it closed. I stepped out of the room, pushed him in and slammed the door closed.

Leaning against the closed door, I checked the tracker, my family were nearly 10 miles out of town. They were out of the danger zone.

I grabbed a piece of paper, scribbled a note and slid it under the closed door. "Never make a villan mad," I heard the fool read before a series of explosions rocked the town.

raw_text: "Hate humanity? What makes you think that? Do you hate the bugs that splatter across your windshields? No, they're just... in the way."
requirements: Feel free to use creativity to expand on the prompt and create an interesting and captivating narrative.
Ensure the story is no shorter than 8000 words.
label:
The summer day was unusually cold when Homer was born. The midwife was called to their manor to deliver him. His mother was convinced that her home was cleanlier than any hospital could ever be. There were complications, but she refused to leave. Eventually, Homer was born a normal healthy baby.

His upbringing was quite bizarre. Their house was located by a public beach, and Homer begged his parents to spend the day there. He wanted to splash in the waves and catalogue shells similar to most adolescents. His parents forbid him for different reasons.

His mother often confided in him about the dangers and germs present in the outside world. The interior of her manor was under her control, and she held onto it by a thread. She spent most of the time in her bedroom that she didn't share with her husband. Homer and his father were required to shower within the past hour before entering. The woman never went to the front door. All chores were done by servants.

Such lifestyle could only be supported by wealth. Homer's paternal and maternal ancestors had it for as back as the line could be traced. His father was a keen investor ensuring that they would stay wealthy for the next several generations. With such wealth, it was simple to gaze upon the matches and convince oneself of grandeur. Homer's father told him that the public beach was where uncouth incompetent cretins went. If his mother allowed it, Homer would attend a private club.

He never went to the beach or boating. Both of his parents' views on the world were well-absorbed by him. The masses were filthy and infected everything they touched. It was best to create a domain of your own. Homer played by himself and was educated by tutors.

When he was a eighteen, his father died of his stroke. His mother became hysterical and refused to leave her bedroom. Supporting her and himself was Homer's responsibility. He rented a townhouse in the posh district of a city, and with his father's money, he went to the stock exchange. He was surprised at the sort of people allowed inside. Few appeared presentable enough to be invited to a dinner party. After a few moments, he left.

With the familial connections, Homer went to a man mentored by his father. Edgar seemed to be a decent man with a firm handshake. Although, Homer disliked touching his hand. Edgar promised to mentor Homer in the ways of finance.

Such a shame that Edgar was a poor student. Within five years, Homer lost a large portion of the family fortune. He had to rent an apartment in an undesirable area, and he had a plumber for a neighbor. His mother passed away as well, and Homer blamed himself for her death.

Grief was not a good motivator. Homer lost more money, and he had to sell the house. With little to do, he went to the library and threw himself into literature. He enjoyed reading about the heroes of old and studied mythology intently.

It was there that he discovered Ilophat. In every mythology, there was a creature that despised humanity. It always attempted to destroy them only to be thwarted by the gods that were powered by the worship of the masses.

Homer related to the snake deity. One look at the city made anyone believe that they failed. The behavior of the gods reflected the poor moral character of the masses. Perhaps Homer should summon Ilophat. He researched further and found a simple summoning ritual.

On a cold summer night similar to his birth, Homer created a circle in the grass from salt Around the circle, he made sigils from the book. In the center, he put a snake in a cage. From his pocket, he produced a rotted grape in a handkerchief and dumped that into the cage. The snake refused to eat it.

"Ilophat." Homer chanted in a voice that wasn't deep, but he tried to give it power. "I summon you to this plain. God of destruction spread chaos and peril across the land."

The snake began to eat the rotted grapes. When it swallowed, its eyes turned a bright purple. Bat wings sprouted from its back, and it flew out of the cage.

"It's been millennia." Ilophat floated before Homer staring into his soul.

"Oh great creature, how I adore you, and your hatred of humanity."

"Hate humanity? Why do you believe that? Do you hate the ants on the ground? No, humans merely exist. Occasionally, they are annoyances."

"But those foolish gods stop you from destroying us time and time again."

"I derive pleasure from torment every so often, and I stop of my own volition. That doesn't stop others from claiming my choices as a result of their actions."

"Please then. Exert torment on this world. We do not deserve it." Homer got on his knees and pleaded. Ilophat smiled.

"No. Your suffering amuses me. I'd much rather explore the new world in this body." Ilophat began to fly away.

"Please. I am a devoted follower. We understand each other."

"You could never hope to understand my true nature maggot." Ilophat shouted as he disappeared into the night. Homer began to cry. He spent his life looking down on others, and he couldn't believe anything would do the same to him.

raw_text: "Conquer" was the last word of the Galactus Emperor. Thus, his people set about a campaign to rule everything by force, in His name. Then they find out a half century later that the data of his last words was corrupted and he'd said, "Conquer fear and bring hope to the galaxy."
requirements: Feel free to use creativity to expand on the prompt and create an interesting and captivating narrative.
Ensure the story is no shorter than 8000 words.
label:
"Conquer," they heard their Galactus Emperor say as he drew his last breath.

And so conquer they did.

The first planet to fall was Mars. Primitive sapients there barely developed metallurgy. How could they hope to match the advanced firepower and space-faring technology of Galacta? The natives of Mars were slaves to the Emperor's forces within a month. To be ruled with fear by an iron fist.

Jupiter was the next to come under Galacta rule. Despite their famed laser guns, the members of the Jupiter Guardians were wiped out by Galacta's nuclear weapons. Without their protectors, the planet's senators surrendered to their conquerors. The top brass would be spared, on the condition that they aid the Emperor's army to enslave their fellow Jupiterians.

One by one, the planets of the Milky Way Galaxy fell under harsh Galacta rule. Their people toiled for over half a day as labourers. Mining precious minerals to fuel the warmachines of the Galacta army. Some spent their lives pouring coffee, providing massage services to their overlords.

For fifty years, all opposition and rebellions were crushed mercilessly. The corpses of rebel leaders and opposing factions hung upon the Great Gates of Galacta as a grisly warning to those who would oppose their rule. Not satisfied by the numerous civilizations under their command, the armies of the long dead Emperor turned their attention to one last planet in the Milky Way Galaxy.

The Terrans were the last remaining bastion against the full might of Galacta. All of Earth's Planetarian Defense gathered, an impressive armada before the Emperor's forces.

"You'll never dominate over Earth! Even if we lose, we'd scorch our Earth than let you have our planet!"

The Galacta General Xyville was unimpressed. "It is by the decree of our late Emperor that we are to conquer."

"Wake up to the smell of bullshit, general," the human response was snarky as hell. "Your Emperor did not rule solely by force and by fear."

"We have his decree here," came the dry remark. "See for yourselves."

"Dude, you're all fucking dumb or what? It says here Conquer fear and bring hope to the galaxy."

"What? What is this blasphemy?" Xyville roared.

"Your data dock was corrupted, so my technicians repaired it to restore the full message. Did nobody think to repair the damned thing for half a century?"

Silence.

"General? Are you there? Cat got your tongue?"

"General, what are your orders?" Xyville's deputy asked. "General?"

"We...have misunderstood our Emperor. We will retreat. We will no longer wage war upon Earth. Upon our return, we must speak with the Galacta Senate. This...this changes everything."

raw_text: You were supposed to be a supervillain. Unfortunately, your monologues were way too convincing. Now you need to figure out how to manage an entire country of rabid supporters.
requirements: Feel free to use creativity to expand on the prompt and create an interesting and captivating narrative.
Ensure the story is no shorter than 8000 words.
label:
I didn't mean for this to happen, it kind of just... happened

Here's the long and short of it, i started as a B team villian, some petty criminal who proved to be a little more trouble than i'm worth, i made my way to the A team, the premiere leagues, the crème de la crème of villians, and eventually, i gained my monicker of "Supervillian"

i'd always had a touch for the showmanship, for the pizzaz, i was a stage actor for petes sake. so i took my role as a supervillian seriously, making big elaborate shows of my most daring stunts, big speeches and even bigger explosions. but one speech got a little away from me.

It started as normal, Captain "Super-freaky super strong awesome man" D was dealing with my goons and bots while i boasted from up above, my speech broadcast all over the country.

"come on, D, don't you get it? you're fighting for nothing! you're fighting to stop true change" i'd started normal, explaining how his position was merely a puppet fill, and how the government that be was the real villian, but ever so deep in his corruption, he didn't believe me

unluckily for me however, the countries people did, they heard my words, and knew i was right, and they started rioting, it was small at first, a couple of drunk kids on a college campus, then it was entire towns, entire states, then the entire country, and here i am now, the god damned president of the united states of america, i'm a villian, not a leader, but i won't let these people down

So i hire the best of the best, i stick to my typical speeches, wacky jokes and the like, keep people on my side, while i insite the laws this country needs, start with an iron fist, return this land to vibrance.

i'd known i went to far when i started using the words "land of opportunity" but there was no turning back

i'd began peace talks all over the world, my former status as supervillian granting me certain privelages, i'd finally done the one thing no one ever thought possible

"Citizens of America, these last years have been long and daunting, but as your president it's been my job, nay, my pleasure to serve you, today marks the day we accomplish something once thought impossible, and many remain unconvinced, but we'll show them the truth before long, of that i can assure you"

"I, the grand supervillian Crafter, have succesfully brokered something magnificent... this is something that will go down in history for the rest of time and beyond"

"I, the president of the united states Karl F Jean, have finally done the impossible"

"peace in our time"

raw_text: Your wife/husband of 35 years comes to you looking dazed. "I fell. I think I hurt my head." You turn them around and are stunned to see a large gash in the back of their head exposing tiny flickering lights and wires.
requirements: Feel free to use creativity to expand on the prompt and create an interesting and captivating narrative.
Ensure the story is no shorter than 8000 words.
label:
Sarah's eyes were glazed over when she stumbled into the living room. "I fell," she mumbled. "My head hurts."

I jumped up from my chair and my bones creaked. Thirty-five years of marriage and Sarah had never looked this confused. I practically ran to her as I held her in my hands, "you'll be alright honey" I said as I carried her to the chair and sat her down. 

"I fell" she slurred with a wide smile on her face

A huge knot started up on my stomach, was she bleeding inside? Was the fall that bad? I gently turned Sarah's head to the side to get a closer look at her cut. The knot in my stomach tightened and dropped as soon as I saw it. It wasn't the wound that got me, it was the lack of a wound. Her skull was filled with tiny wires and blinking lights, instead of bone and muscles it was all just metal. 

​​"John?" Sarah's voice sounded far away. "What's wrong?" 

"You're okay, baby" I said trying to hide the crack in my voice "Just a little rest and you'll be good as new"

Sarah reached for me. Her fingers brushed my arm, and I flinched away without thinking. She looked hurt that I'd pulled away, the hurt in her eyes, it looked real. It looked so human, it made me want to scream.

"You're bleeding," I managed to choke out. "Sit down. I'll get the first aid kit."

I stumbled to the bathroom and barely managed to lock the door behind me before I fell on top of the sink. I couldn't recognize the face in the mirror, what was going on. My face was pale and my eyes were wide with terror .I splashed water on my face but it didn't help "This is just a dream, just a big bad dream" I whisper to myself, pacing in the bathroom

My mind was racing. Thirty-five years of marriage, two kids, countless memories. Was it all a lie? I felt sick to my stomach. I had to get back out there, had to face whatever the hell was going on. But my legs wouldn't move. I was frozen, I couldn't look away from the mirror.

"JOHN, JOHN" Sarashs voice yelled from across the house "WHERE ARE YOU?" It was weird, she sounded terrified as she called for me, she sounded scared 

I swallowed hard, trying to get rid of the lump in my throat "I'm coming honey" 

A knock on the door made me jump not even a  second after I had replied back to my wife. "John?" it was Sarah's voice. It sounded normal now, concerned. "Are you okay in there?"

I took a deep breath, grabbed the first aid kit from behind the mirror, and opened the door with a wide smile on my face. Sarah was standing there, looking worried. 

"Now let's take a look at that cut," I said, trying to keep my voice steady.

As I reached to turn her head, Sarah caught my wrist without even a glance at my arm. Her grip was strong. Far too strong.

"Sweetie," she said softly. "I know you know, Theres something I need to show you."

Sarah led me to our bedroom, her hand still clasped around my wrist as she dragged me alone. She reached under the bed and pulled out an old, leather-bound book. I recognized it immediately - it was the diary she'd kept when we first met, the one she'd always said was too personal to share.

"I think it's time you read this," she said, her voice barely above a whisper.

I opened the diary, what was going on? I didn't know how to feel as I read the first few pages. They were filled with hundreds of observations about human behavior. It was written in a detached neutral tone, it was almost freaky how little emotions were behind her words

The more I flipped through the pages the more, I saw my name appearing more and more frequently. I kept flipping through the pages, faster and faster, I wasn't even reading the words on the pages anymore, I just wanted this nightmare to be over

All the entries about me just referred to me as her subject. "Subject John displays typical human mating behaviors," one read. "He appears to view me as a potential mate. The pet could prove useful for my mission."

My heart sank as I read entry after entry describing me as little more than a test subject, she kept calling me her pet to be studied and manipulated. Tears began to well up in my eyes, I could see a few wet drops fall on the old brown pages of her journal as the teras began to fall down my face without a care in the world.

"I'm a pet?" I questioned, looking at the pages, my eyes wouldn't move from the word. The word "Pet" 

"I haven't felt that way in a long time, John," she said, she sounded almost sad. "What you read at the beginning - that was before that was all wrong. Who I am now is someone else, I can love, John. You taught me that. You made me who I am and I love you."

"I'm just a pet" I repeated

​​"I have made a decision that goes against everything I was programmed for when I was sent to observe. I chose you John. I choose love. I choose humanity, with all its flaws, because then I got to have you. Whatever I was before, whatever my original purpose was, it no longer matters and it nevers has. I am Sarah, and I am in love."

She took my hands in hers, her touch was just as soft as I had always remembered it, not like the tight grip she had on me before. "I know this is a lot to take in," she said, moving my head up to look at her now. "I know you must have a thousand questions. But please believe me when I say that my love for you, for our children, for the life we've built together - it's all real. It's the most real thing I've ever known."

The sun shined through the window, shining a beautiful yellow light on her face, lighting up her beautiful emerald green eyes even more than usual. "I love you, John"
